results.content: I like his style. It assumes nothing, but gives clear, straightforward explanations and examples. TBH, I've been fuzzy on what exactly a function's parameters and arguments were, as well as a function statement and function expression. I felt that even though I'd heard it explained many, many times, his simple, clear style allowed these concepts to finally make sense to me. That's why I haven't been skipping around, and I look forward to having any other ambiguities cleared up, as well.

results.content:
Good course, actually one of the best here at Udemy!
You get the theory and the demo project all from scratch!
good working code and slides ratio.
Things i missed: json and xml parsing, some examples on good practices in java script programming like for example unit testing.
Overall not bat, not bad at all, i can recommend it to anyone, who has previous exposure of another programming languages like Java or C++.
results.content_html:
Good course, actually one of the best here at Udemy!
You get the theory and the demo project all from scratch!
good working code and slides ratio.
Things i missed: json and xml parsing, some examples on good practices in java script programming like for example unit testing.
Overall not bat, not bad at all, i can recommend it to anyone, who has previous exposure of another programming languages like Java or C++.

results.content: Course covers Javascript theory explained clearly and  straightforward.  As in case of all CodeAndCreate courses all lectures are well organized and structured- there is no jumping from one topic to another, syntax is presented in nice, clear way, there is also nice comparison for es5 and es6; I also liked the fact each section ends with quiz- where I could test what I have learnt and see where I have to improve. I personally lacked some more projects referring to DOM manipulation or functionality of JS used for websites or applications for better reference and structuring of what I was learning and applying this step by step to modern projects. If more such projects are added to the course I would be happy to update to 5 stars. Speaking form beginners perspective in programming: Quiz project is nice- but too advance, although you learn all the syntax you may get lost...therefore something inbeetwen would be more than appreciated :)
results.content_html: Course covers Javascript theory explained clearly and straightforward. As in case of all CodeAndCreate courses all lectures are well organized and structured- there is no jumping from one topic to another, syntax is presented in nice, clear way, there is also nice comparison for es5 and es6; I also liked the fact each section ends with quiz- where I could test what I have learnt and see where I have to improve. I personally lacked some more projects referring to DOM manipulation or functionality of JS used for websites or applications for better reference and structuring of what I was learning and applying this step by step to modern projects. If more such projects are added to the course I would be happy to update to 5 stars. Speaking form beginners perspective in programming: Quiz project is nice- but too advance, although you learn all the syntax you may get lost...therefore something inbeetwen would be more than appreciated :)

results.content:
The concepts are made simple to understand. The explanation is pretty clear.
The approaches to the syllabus is very well organized. Like, what is needed to pass through a certain point of the lecture seems to be predetermined.


Only one issue to be noted. There seems to be a mistake in the lecture about Maps and Sets (ES6).
This issue need not be considered serious, as we are in a scripting domain. So the working and results are important.

In the lecture it is said that there are only values in Sets compared to key-value pairs in map. This might be wrong (I'm not sure). Why I'm telling this is because it is usually the keys which are part of the hashing function. Ans it is because of hashing that the set can have unique entries/values.
So it might be that "set is nothing but a map in which the value is the same as the key".
Please check this.
results.content_html:
The concepts are made simple to understand. The explanation is pretty clear.
The approaches to the syllabus is very well organized. Like, what is needed to pass through a certain point of the lecture seems to be predetermined.

Only one issue to be noted. There seems to be a mistake in the lecture about Maps and Sets (ES6).
This issue need not be considered serious, as we are in a scripting domain. So the working and results are important.

In the lecture it is said that there are only values in Sets compared to key-value pairs in map. This might be wrong (I'm not sure). Why I'm telling this is because it is usually the keys which are part of the hashing function. Ans it is because of hashing that the set can have unique entries/values.
So it might be that "set is nothing but a map in which the value is the same as the key".
Please check this.

results.content:
I am only half-way through the course.  I love how he uses the console and shows you "EXACTLY" what is going on.  This is probably the best JS course out for learning and completely understanding how to use JS. 

My best advice, mix this course with "understanding the weird parts" and you will have a great understanding of JS

Not only that, the response times were extremely fast to my questions.  I HIGHLY recommend any beginner/intermediate to take this course because you will understand practical use purposes as well as him showing you why the console is so important.  

Also, he gives you pretty difficult quizzes which really help you understand why being precise is important and his projects are perfect to lead you in. 

I wish I could give this course 10 stars.  Please continue to create courses like this in other aspects as we can continue to work with you. I know you said you had a CSS class. I would love the link for that if you could shoot that over because the class I'm taking isn't what I expected.

response.content:
Thank you Michael for your kind words.
Glad to hear that you are enjoying the course.
response.content_html:
Thank you Michael for your kind words.
Glad to hear that you are enjoying the course.

I am only half-way through the course. I love how he uses the console and shows you "EXACTLY" what is going on. This is probably the best JS course out for learning and completely understanding how to use JS.

My best advice, mix this course with "understanding the weird parts" and you will have a great understanding of JS

Not only that, the response times were extremely fast to my questions. I HIGHLY recommend any beginner/intermediate to take this course because you will understand practical use purposes as well as him showing you why the console is so important.

Also, he gives you pretty difficult quizzes which really help you understand why being precise is important and his projects are perfect to lead you in.

I wish I could give this course 10 stars. Please continue to create courses like this in other aspects as we can continue to work with you. I know you said you had a CSS class. I would love the link for that if you could shoot that over because the class I'm taking isn't what I expected.

results.content:
Świetny kurs - instruktor omawia zagadnienia w sposób bardzo dokładny i obszerny. Nie ma tutaj częstego w kursach online chodzenia na skróty. Wręcz przeciwnie - instruktor poświęca czas na wyjaśnienie kwestii stanowiących teoretyczne podstawy dla pisania kodu.
Pod koniec kursu (~60%) robi się jednak dość trudno.

results.content: The series starts strong. Things are well explained and make sense. Starting with section 5, things seem to go off the rails. It becomes incredibly complex and, while things are shown, there is no context to explain why you would do these types of things in a program and they are so similar that without any context it is very confusing. If it's confusing or doesn't make sense why you would use it, it makes it harder to remember even if it will be something used later. I think if things were explained more as to the "why" this would be a really good course. However, as is, it's like being given a 1000 piece puzzle where all the pieces are just plain white. Sure, eventually it might all fit together, but it's going to be a heck of a frustrating time putting it together.

If it's confusing or doesn't make sense why you would use it, it makes it harder to remember even if it will be something used later. I think if things were explained more as to the "why" this would be a really good course. However, as is, it's like being given a 1000 piece puzzle where all the pieces are just plain white. Sure, eventually it might all fit together, but it's going to be a heck of a frustrating time putting it together.

results.content: I love that the instructor takes the time to explain how to setup your coding environment and how to use Chrome developer tools as well as hot keys to speed up development. He takes the time to explain all the details I need as a beginner to JavaScript and addresses all of the issues I might have before I have them. I love that the tools used are opensource and freely available. I also love the price of this course and the quality of the content. Udemy is doing a great job here. I feel like Udemy courses are a great replacement for community college courses and saves me time and money compared to going to classes at a community college. Keep up the good work. I intend to take a ton of Udemy courses to learn how to be a full stack web developer and build mobile apps with react. Thanks again and keep up the good work. This instructor is fantastic!
